subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] BPJ's roposal for QS-SAMPA ligatures and half-letters
msgSnippet: My personal opinion is that half Whitewheat and half Win make reading a lot more difficult. Moira ... -- Moira O Brien Tel UK:    +44 7831-625990 (UK) Tel Eire
messageBody:
My personal opinion is that half Whitewheat and half Win make reading a lot more difficult.

Moira

On 10/12/2007, Ted Larson Freeman < freeman@...> wrote:
I think this is a solid, well-thought-out proposal. I'll suggest a
name for it: "QS-SAMPA Extended".

Until we have it implemented in a font, it's difficult to evaluate
fully. In the meantime, I just have one question. Should there also be
a half-Whitewheat, ie half-{W}?

Ted


On Dec 10, 2007 3:11 AM, Benct Philip Jonsson <bpj@...> wrote:
>
>
>
>
>
>
> # Corrected presentation of BPJ's proposal for
>  QS-SAMPA ligatures and half-letters
>
>  This one is with one exception, which is a correction,
>  a superset of the old one, and thus backwards
>  compatible, inserting some omissions -- notably half-t.
>  Please scrap the old version!
>
>  In the following QS letters and spellings are given
>  according to QS-SAMPA and enclosed in curly braces {lYk
>  DIs}, TO letters and spellings are given between
>  underscores _like this_. English phonemes are given in
>  slashes /laIk DIs/ in a SAMPA transcription modified
>  towards QS-SAMPA in that /y/ and /a/ are used rather
>  than /@/ and /{/. Phonetic transcription where
>  necessary is given in a similarly modified SAMPA in
>  square brackets [lyIk Dys].
>
>  My proposal is propose that *if* ligatures are to be
>  assigned to positions in QS-SAMPA this should better
>  not be done randomly, since the whole idea with QS-
>  SAMPA is to make QS-to-ASCII mappings less random.
>  Seeing that the letter positions in the ASCII range are
>  essentially used up by the basic QS letters, the most
>  consistent manner of catering for ligatures would be to
>  assign them to positions corresponding to accented
>  letters in the Latin-1 encoding, so that e.g. a vowel
>  with a particular accent mark stands for 'the
>  corresponding QS-SAMPA vowel with following {r}' and
>  another accent mark for 'following {n}', a third for
>  'preceding {j} or {I}'.
>
>  Personally I regard ligatures as 'typographic sugar'
>  which should be regarded as by no means necessary or
>  required in ordinary typing. Looking in QM one sees
>  that those vowel+{r} combinations which happen to
>  correspond to lexical sets do *not* receive special
>  treatment compared to other combined letter sequences
>  in Read's QS handwriting. It seems to me the whole
>  business of ligatures in QS fonts is a carryover from
>  Shavian typography, but as some people like them, and
>  the vowel+{r} combination do correspond to single
>  sounds in non-rhotic accents they should be catered
>  for.
>
>  ## The assignments
>
>  On p. 13 of QM Read gives what he intends as a full
>  list of vowel+r ligatures, which would give us
>
>  - {Er} = {É} (_merry_)
>  - {er} = {é} (_Mary_)
>  - {ar} = {á} (_marry_)
>  - {Yr} = {Ý} (_mire_)
>  - {Ar} = {Á} (_mar_)
>  - {Or} = {Ó} (_more_)
>  - {ur} = {ú} (_moor_)
>  - {ir} = {í} (_mere_)
>  - {yr} = {ý} (_murder_)
>  - {Hr} = {ø} (_sour_)
>
>  Correspondingly, with following {n}
>
>  - {En} = {Ë} (_pen_)
>  - {en} = {ë} (_pain, pane_)
>  - {an} = {ä} (_pan_)
>  - {Yn} = {Ÿ} (_pine_)
>  - {An} = {Ä} (_Juan_)
>  - {On} = {Ö} (_pawn_)
>  - {on} = {ö} (_bone_)
>  - {un} = {ü} (_soon_)
>  - {in} = {ï} (_wean_)
>  - {yn} = {ÿ} (_pun_)
>  - {Hn} = {Ø} (_town_)
>
>  Also, though less systematic, with preceding {j} or {I}
>
>  - {ju} = {ù} (_cute_)
>  - {jur} = {Ù} (_cure_)
>  - {jyn} = {Ò} (_onion, million)
>  - {Iy} = {à} (_India_)
>  - {Iyn} = {À} (_Indian_)
>  - {Iyr} = {È} (_windier_)
>
>  This leaves the capitals _P, L, M, B, C, F_ free to
>  assign to the half-letters and the {Vl} ligature:
>
>  - half-{p} = {P} (obvious, I hope)
>  - {Vl} = {L} (_ultra_)
>  - half-{w} = {M} (_M_ is upside-down _W_)
>  - half-{h} = {B} (_B_ is visually similar to _H_)
>  - half-{z} = {C} (_C_ is visually similar to the QS
>  half- {z}, and _c_ is sometimes
>  /s/, the voiceless counterpart to
>  /z/...)
>  - half-{T} = {F} (vague visual similarity between _F_
>  and _T_)
>
>  And in addition:
>
>  - half-{d} = {Ð} (_Ed_)
>  - alt-{D} = {ð} (_other_ {Qðyr}, [ð] is IPA for
>  SAMPA [D])
>
>  ## Notes on the assignments
>
>  The use of Hr = ø and Hn = Ø is made necessary by the
>  fact that there is no accented H's! I hope the slash on
>  ø and Ø will recall the crossbar on H.
>
>  The letter _Ÿ_ (capital Y with dieresis) is not
>  included in the Latin-1 encoding, but it is included in
>  Windows-1252 encoding as character 159, and it can
>  hardly hurt to include an {Yn} ligature, if desired, as
>  character 159 in a QS-SAMPA font.
>
>  With the acute accent essentially meaning 'preceding j
>  or I' those assignments are admittedly not as
>  systematic. However {Iy} often corresponds to TO _ia_,
>  {Iyr} to TO _ier_ and {Iyn} to TO _ian_, which
>  hopefully can work as memory cues.
>
>  Words like _cure_ are given with [jUy(r)] in the
>  pronunciation dictionaries. The CMUPD gives some items
>  with [ju(y)r], but they are all foreign names. It thus
>  seems reasonable to assume that [Uy(r)] corresponding
>  to _ur_ + vowel is phonemically /jur/ and should be
>  written {jur} in QS. I've looked for examples in QM
>  without finding any, which isn't to say there aren't
>  any. NB that I mistyped {jur} as {jyr} in the first
>  version of this proposal.
>
>  QM gives a ligature (or spelling) {jyn} corresponding
>  to the spelling _ion_ in the words _onion, minion,
>  pillion, million_. It seems defensible to map this
>  ligature {jyn} {Ò} by analogy with {Ian} = {À}.
>
>  Perhaps {Ð} and {ð} should be swapped so that alt-{D}
>  is {Ð} and half-{d} is {ð}? All the other half-letters
>  are assigned to capitals however, and the IPA [ð] =
>  SAMPA [D] *is* a rather solid memory cue, IMHO.
>
>  These mappings to accented letters may be hard to type
>  with a standard British or American keyboard mapping
>  but they are infinitely more readable, and if someone
>  is in a situation where they are hard to type these
>  ligatures are after all simply dispensible. They are
>  easy to type with the US International keyboard layout,
>  which works reasonably well also with a British-Irish
>  physical keyboard. For information on these issues, see
>
>  <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/British_and_American_keyboards>.
>
>  Last but not least: I am among those who find the
>  assignment of alt-{n} to _q_ bothersome, but I have
>  found a useable memory cue, in that both alt-{n} and
>  _q_ can be seen as circles with lines coming out at the
>  bottom.
>
>  /BP 8^)>
>  --
>  Benct Philip Jonsson -- melroch atte melroch dotte se
>  ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
>  No man forgets his original trade: the rights of
>  nations and of kings sink into questions of grammar,
>  if grammarians discuss them.
>  -Dr. Samuel Johnson (1707 - 1784)
